results.title: WHO: The kids are alright
results.creator_credit: Jeff Stein, Bill Curbishley, Tony Klinger and BMG Music
results.brief_description: Features live performances of the Who’s most celebrated hits from “My generation” to the sophistication of the rock opera “Tommy”. Along with the guitar-smashing exuberance of the group’s stage performances, director Jeff Stein has assembled a series of interviews which reflect the collective and individual nature of the band.

results.title: Duran Duran
results.creator_credit: Russell Mulcahy and Educational Media International
results.brief_description: A collection of Duran Duran first eleven videotapes. Two of the clips “Girls on film” and “Chauffeur” contain material which would have a theatrical “M” rating. Adult preview recommended.

results.title: Great Grand Finals
results.creator_credit: Seven Network Limited (Australia) and Victorian Football League
results.brief_description: Coverage by HSV 7 of the 1983 Grand Final between Essendon and Hawthorn. Also great moments from grand finals of the past: St Kilda’s first premiership 1966, Carlton’s amazing comeback 1970, North Melbourne & Collingwood draw 1977, Carlton & Richmond 1973, Richmond & Geelong 1967 and Nth Melbourne’s first flag in 1975.

results.title: Perigord cuisine
results.creator_credit: Regis Dervelle and BCD France - TV Ontario Canada
results.brief_description: Provides an overview of the cuisine of the Perigord region in France. Shows the harvesting of the food items used as ingredients. Presents a demostration on how to cook some dishes from the region including scrambled eggs with truffles, truffle feullette, and mousse de foie gras covered with ham and flaky pastry.

results.title: Energy Conservation in the Home
results.creator_credit: Dept of Minerals and Energy AV Workshop
results.brief_description:
“Energy conservation in the home” provides useful information on the ways in which energy can be saved within the household.

See also Related Title 325491 “Victoria’s energy”; uses stills to analyse Victoria’s energy position during 1980-81.

results.title: Cracking the egg
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at eggs. Considers the variations in size shape, texture and structure. Notes the origins of the egg, how it forms, the incubation differences by parent birds, hatching and the fate of the residual shell. Also touches on the so called bionic egg, egg collecting, the domestication of wildfowl, the egg’s place in folklore, its uses in the culinary arts, its influence in the decorative arts, the egg marketing industry, Easter eggs and artificial eggs.

results.title: Lord of the rings
results.creator_credit: Ralph Bakshi, Saul Zaentz, Fantasy Films and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: J. R. R. Tolkien’s massive three volume saga tells the story of how a few brave individuals manage to avert the Apocalypse by their boldness, chivalry, self-sacrifice and faith. Ralph Bakshi, America’s foremost new-style animator, translates this “impossible dream” into a full-length cartoon in a way that respects Tolkien’s story and inspiration, turning a literary classic into a magical visual experience. A large cast of mainly British voices, including John Hurt’s, excites the discriminating ear as much as the movie enchants the eye. Peter S. Beagle co-wrote the screenplay with Chris Conkling.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Bakshi, Saul Zaentz, Fantasy Films and United Artists Corporation

results.title: Ballad of Joe Hill
results.brief_description: Joseph Hillstrom, a young Swedish migrant to America in 1902, found prejudice and corruption instead of the equality and opportunity he was expecting. Disturbed by the injustices suffered by workers, Joe Hillstrom became an organizer of the Industrial Workers of the World, the legendary big union with anarchist reputation.

results.title: Louise Drouin: veterinarian
results.creator_credit: Margaret Wescott, Louise Spence and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A portrait of a country veterinarian, working mother, and partner in a thriving practice. In the film, Dr. Drouin shares many facets of her life: at work in her surgery, making “house calls” that take her over a hundred miles from home, and rare moments of relaxation with her husband and child. Articulate and forthright, she talks about the joys and sorrows of being a veterinarian, and how she balances the demands of a busy profession with those of raising a family.
